title: Friday afternoon Cardinal news and notes
body_text:
Semi-back from strep hell just in time for weekend two of the football season.
Friday afternoon Cardinal news and notes
Twenty-four hours until fans of all ages are back inside L&N Stadium.
Love kids.
—Spread Check: Louisville by 30.
—Louisville has jumped from No. 31 to No. 18 in Bill Connelly’s S&P Rankings.
—Attention U of L alums/fans looking to make the trip to Notre Dame: The U of L alumni association has two chapters — Chicago and Indianapolis — taking bus trips to the game. They are “traveling tailgates,” so there will be music, games, and giveaways during the ride. Fans are encouraged to bring their own drinks/snacks (only rule - no glass). The cost is $50 per seat.
The groups will be parking the buses at the LaSalle Council Boy Scout Office. The CEO there (John Cary) is a U of L alum and former Student Body President.
More information on both trips can be found at the links below.
Chicago: http://UofLAlumni.org/2024-ChicagoND
Indianapolis: http://UofLAlumni.org/2024-IndyND
For the Indy trip, they do have some people driving in from Louisville or Cincinnati and taking the bus the rest of the way, so that’s an option.
For Chicago, if anyone is making a Chicago weekend of it, they are putting together a group outing to the Reds at Cubs game on Friday afternoon at 1:20pm: http://UofLAlumni.org/2024-ChicagoCubsgame
—Despite some not so great results in week one, Jacksonville State is sticking with a two quarterback offense in week two.
—The best part of Lamar Jackson feature in GQ (which is worth a full read) is him essentially referring to Miami as “an ass school.”
Still, despite his one-of-one abilities, superstardom has never been a seamless fit for Jackson. Petrino says Jackson loathed certain aspects of the college recruiting process so much that he ultimately committed to Louisville without even visiting. By the way, if you’re questioning how a prospect like Jackson wound up in Kentucky, rather than his hometown University of Miami, the interest, Lamar felt, was not mutual. “Miami was my favorite school,” he says. But the team’s coach seemed uninterested in local talent, to Jackson’s unending frustration. “We’re the ones who made Miami what it was! When they started recruiting everyone else, they was sorry as hell. All the talent, all the real athletes, they were from here. Man, I’m not going there to be ass. That was my favorite school, but I don’t want to be at an ass school.”
While the old guard still prefers quarterbacks to be more war general and less laid-back jokester, Jackson thrives with a loose, unburdened mindset. The more stone-faced and tense everyone around him is, the less he feels like himself. Perhaps his most dominant game in college was the time he put up five touchdowns to topple a Florida State team that had won 53 of its last 59 games. Before that game, Jackson tells me, he was prancing around the locker room wearing an offensive lineman’s cleats. Bullshitting, in his words, and not in the way quarterbacks usually do. The problem with so many modern athletes, he thinks, is simple. “Everybody’s so serious! When you’re too serious, I feel like you’re scared. I’m like, ‘Let’s get it. They can’t fuck with me.’”
“I don’t wan to be at an ass school.”
Put that on a shirt before Oct. 19.
—The Athletic’s Chris Vannini has Louisville at No. 32 in his weekly ranking of all 134 FBS teams.
—Cardinal Authority looks at the opening week of the NFL for former Cards in the league.
—Future Cardinal Antonio Harris wants to be the latest Male High Bulldog to go on to star at U of L. Harris and company will face St. X tonight in their first major challenge of the season.
—The latest episode of the CC Podcast is here.
—The future?
—Louisville has its first commitment from the Class of 2026, with in-state offensive lineman Max Merz (Highlands) pledging his allegiance to the Cards.
—Matt McGavic highlights the points of emphasis for Louisville vs. Jacksonville State.
—Jadon Thompson has limited experience playing in the slot, but he accepted and excelled in the week one challenge with Caullin Lacy out.
—Due to inclement weather in the forecast, the 7th-ranked Louisville field hockey team’s Friday home opener against Princeton has been moved up to 1 p.m.
Here’s the updated full schedule for the ACC/Ivy League Challenge:

—Fresh off their first loss of the season at Penn State on Tuesday, the 4th-ranked Louisville volleyball team is hitting the road this weekend for three matches at the Northern Kentucky Invitational. Here’s a preview.
—The Louisville women’s soccer team remained unbeaten with a 2-0 win over UT-Martin on Thursday night.
—On3’s latest college football bracketology has Louisville on the bubble.
—Mark Redman came to Louisville to bolster the use of the tight end in the passing game. He did just that in week one.
Redman brought in his lone catch of the day in the endzone for a 21-yard score near two Governors defenders. The Cardinals tight end spoke to the accuracy of the pass from quarterback Tyler Shough which put him in prime position to secure the touchdown grab.
“It was something we practiced for weeks on end coming into fall camp,” Redman noted. “If you look at the catch, it was good. If you look at the pass, it was better. If the pass was two inches higher or lower, it wouldn’t have happened. Shout out to the whole team for that play.”
Redman attributed his success to being able to face the Cardinals tough defense in practice. Louisville’s defensive effort held Austin Peay to 108 yards of total offense on Saturday.
“I personally go against Ashton Gillotte, Ramon (Puryear), Adonijah (Green), and all of those defensive line guys in practice. It shows what the defense can do with seven sacks and 14 TFLs. When I saw that after the game, it surprised me a little, but I knew those guys were capable of that. I was impressed by the defense.”
—Athlon’s college football writers pick the winner of every week two college football game. All three like Louisville to handle business against Jacksonville State.
—Louisville’s CFP championship odds somehow went up from 150/1 to 200/1 on BetOnline after their week 1 stomping of Austin Peay.
—The Louisville baseball team will open the 2025 season at the Shriners Children’s College Showdown at Globe Life Field in Arlington, Texas. The Cards will go up against Texas on opening night (Feb. 14) in the primetime slot with first pitch scheduled for 8 p.m. ET. U of L will then play Oklahoma State on Feb. 15 at 4 p.m. ET and wrap up against Arizona on Feb. 16 at 11:30 a.m. ET.
—After watching the team in The Bahamas, Rob Dauster and Terrence Oglesby discuss why they think Louisville can win the ACC.
—Paying players is “legal” now, and SMU has a ton of multi-millionaire backers. That could make the Mustangs a force in ACC football in the years to come.
—The proposed House v. NCAA settlement suddenly feels much more tenuous after Thursday’s preliminary approval hearing.
—The process of getting Ahmari Huggins-Bruce back up to speed after returning to Louisville is still ongoing, but Jeff Brohm is happy to have him back.
—C.L. Brown writes that Louisville’s special teams appear poised to win the Cardinals games this season, something he says wasn’t the case a year ago.
—First victory tape of the year is glorious:
—IN-STATE PETTY RIVALRY MOVE ALERT: Western Kentucky was planning a “White Out” game Saturday versus Eastern Kentucky, but the Colonels decided at the last second to wear white jerseys as visitors. WKU fans will still wear white, but the team will have to wear their home red.
—Athlon says Georgia Tech and NC State are two of the three most overrated teams in the current AP top 25.
—Harry Douglas will be inducted into the U of L Ring of Honor during the Cards’ home game against Georgia Tech in two Saturdays. Harry will be in town all weekend.
—Jarvis Brownlee, who transferred to Louisville after multiple seasons at Florida State, did not hate watching the Seminoles fall to 0-2.
—Steve Lassan of Athlon has Louisville facing LSU in the Gator Bowl in his latest bowl projections.
—Over the last few months, Memphis State has seen seven assistants (including Rick Stansbury this week) leave the program, and now the acknowledgement of an anonymous letter alleging rules violations in the program that it has turned over to the NCAA.
Outside of that it’s goin’ great.
—ACC schools have a new path to more revenue: Win in the postseason, keep more of the money generated by your own postseason success.
—Both of Jacksonville State’s quarterbacks being in the top 10 here isn’t great ... at least not for them.
—Louisville spent time this week visiting with former Washington County standout Gabe Weis (2026). The forward has transferred Montverde Academy for his junior season.
—Louisvillian Oksana Masters won her 8th Paralympic gold medal this week.
—Pat Kelsey and company are turning up the heat on their recruitment of five-star Nate Ament.
—Andrea Adelson has Louisville at No. 8 in her weekly ACC power rankings.
—ESPN’s Eric MacLain has the Cards at No. 2.
—This is now Clemson football.
—Fern Creek lineman Travis Moten is committed to Western Michigan, but was a guest of U of L’s for last week’s game against Austin Peay and will be back again for tomorrow’s game against Jacksonville State.
—Louisville safety commit Micah Rice was impressed by the Cardinals defense in the season-opener.
—Darryn Peterson, the No. 1 ranked shooting guard in the 2025 class, has narrowed his list to four schools. It no longer includes Louisville.
—Flattery will get you everywhere, Rich Rod ... except, you know, when it’s unwanted flattery in a workplace environment with a woman who’s not your wife. Then it gets you to Jacksonville State.
—Louisville volleyball players took home the ACC’s first Defensive Player and Freshman of the Week honors.
—Top 50 prospect Xavier Tiller says Louisville unofficial visit “was so lit.” Is the fact that he didn’t say “litty” a bad sign for the Cards? Language experts say, “we don’t know, please stop emailing us with this bullshit.”
—Congrats to Ben Perry on picking up the very first Card Chronicle Teammate of the Week award for 2024.
—The Cleveland Browns named Jamari Thrash as the team’s Maurice Bassett Award recipient, which goes to the rookie who performed the best during the preseason.
—Pat Kelsey has offered class of 2026 power forward Toni Bryant.
—You can get discounted tickets to tonight’s and/or Tuesday night’s Lou City match by going right here.
—The unbeaten, untied U of L men’s soccer team starts ACC play Friday night with a huge test against No. 7 Notre Dame. The Fighting Irish were national runners-up a year ago.
—I like this.
—Peny Boone rushed for 81 yards on 11 carries in UCF’s season-opening romp over New Hampshire. The CJ keeps tabs on how other Louisville defectors fared in week one.
—In two days on the recruiting trail, Pat Kelsey hit six different states.
—Louisville Report has highlights and an evaluation of new O-line commit Max Merz.
—And finally, beat Jacksonville State.
